awd_titl_txt: 25th Anniversary GLOBE Annual Meeting:  Reflecting on the Past, Looking to the Future, 2019-0479
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1
At its 2020 annual meeting, the GLOBE national and global education community will share current practices, research, and strategies for bringing Earth system education to more schools and citizen scientists around the world. This includes both data collection with popular GLOBE science protocols and protocols of interest to the community and best practices for integrating GLOBE into classrooms, informal education programs, with undergraduate students, with interested citizens and with the research community more broadly. Additionally, through a retrospective look at GLOBE over the 25 years of the program, participants will have the opportunity to learn about long-term involvement with GLOBE and how GLOBE has changed over the years. Through the work with the Diversity and Inclusion Task Force and its recommendations, participants will have the potential to reach even more people in their own communities. Additionally, students attending the meeting will obtain experience discussing their research with peers and scientists from around the world as well as tools on how to discuss Earth system science with their families and communities.

Part 2
At the Annual Meeting, the theme of Reflecting on the Past, Looking to the Future will be explored further in multiple strands. These strands are: 1) A Welcoming GLOBE; 2) Collaborations Around the World; 3) 25 Years of GLOBE; and 4) The Next 25 Years. Additionally, trainers and mentor trainers will train participants in the top five GLOBE protocols and the top five requested protocols at the meeting. The GLOBE participants will learn about the GLOBE Diversity and Inclusion Task Force recommendations for making more GLOBE more welcoming and inclusive. GLOBE students will learn about science storytelling and how to share their knowledge with their schools, communities, and families. GLOBE teachers from non-traditional schools (e.g., schools focused on learners with disabilities, talented and gifted, etc.) will be invited to participate and share at the meeting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Global Learning and Observations to Benefit the Environment (GLOBE) Program is an international science and education program that brings together K-12 students, teachers, scientists as well as citizen scientists to build a collaborative, worldwide community to conduct real-world research. Students can conduct research with the data collected from the program's scientific protocols.  These span the four Earth spheres, atmosphere, biosphere, hydrosphere and pedosphere. The 55 protocols have led to over 212 million measurements submitted to the GLOBE database.  Every year the GLOBE Implementation Office (GIO) hosts an annual meeting that members of this international community can attend, learn scientific, educational, and technological updates about the program from staff, as well as reporting on their engagement with the community and the program.

The theme for the annual meeting was "Adapting to a Changing GLOBE” and was hosted virtually from 12-16 July, 2021.  Three strands were developed that would showcase the work of the community especially in the COVID era.  These were STEM Teaching and GLOBE; A Welcoming GLOBE; and Responding to a Changing GLOBE.

 

The major goals associated with these strands were:

  • to examine the use of GLOBE as a component of STEM Teaching,
  • to create an even more inclusive, ‘welcoming’ environment within the GLOBE community as the diversity of countries continues to grow,
  • showing examples of how the community can utilize the program to respond to the many changes occurring in our world (scientific, environmental, social, etc.)
  • to expand the number of community presentations over the previous meeting, as a way to increase community engagement with each other and the program, and
  • to increase the interactivity of this virtual meeting over the previous one in 2020.

Strands were integrated into the meeting agenda and each one had several sessions where community members presented their work in the local community in their countries. In addition, there were online GLOBE Science Protocol sessions in which participants could enroll to learn more about these components of the program.  In addition, just like the in-person meetings, a student experience was part of event.  GIO staff and GLOBE community volunteers staffed this experience.  Students were selected randomly for each region based on independent assessments from STEM professionals of their International Virtual Science Symposium (IVSS) research projects. 

Three hundred and fifty-two (352) registrants from 51 GLOBE Countries attended the meeting. Participants included 40 students who were selected among top projects from the 2021 IVSS and participated in a virtual Student Experience.

The schedule began between 7 and 8 am Mountain Time (Monday through Thursday) and generally ended by 1pm each day.  Further sessions were available later in the day for networking and technology clinics.  The meeting included 66 sessions over the course of the week.  One hundred and fourteen adults presented on topics that spanned the three strands.   Forty student speakers showcased their IVSS projects for a total of 17 student presentations.

At the end of the meeting an evaluation form was disseminated to the attendees.  Results from the evaluation show that:

  • 94% of survey respondents [n=97] rated the overall event as “Good” or “Excellent”
  • Less than 3% of survey respondents rated the event as below average
  • The event was exceedingly organized and managed in comparison to other virtual conferences they have attended
  • One barrier to participation during the meeting was that 20% of survey respondents had difficulties accessing sessions and content during the meeting. This challenge was based on 3 factors:

o   1) technical difficulties with the meeting platform website;

o   2) too many disparate platforms and pages for meeting content; and

o   3) poor internet connections which created poor quality on livestreamed
    sessions and when connecting to collaborative sessions.

  • The GLOBE Student Showcase was by far the most enjoyed aspect of the meeting. This falls in line with survey results from previous GLOBE meetings.  Learning from the students about their GLOBE research is typically the most popular session.
  • Respondents liked the protocol sessions and community sessions. It was also noted that the variety in session types (e.g., report outs, trainings, networking, etc.) kept the meeting engaging.
  • Requests to expand the protocol sessions were notes by either:

o   1) lengthening the time for the sessions;

o   2) having more specific examples or applications of the protocols; or

o   3) increasing interactive time to practice the protocol in the session.

 

Overall, the second all-virtual GLOBE Annual Meeting was a rewarding event. GIO was pleased to see strong community attendance from many GLOBE countries, especially with an ongoing pandemic and the necessary virtual nature of the event. The many passionate and productive comments will support planning efforts for subsequent meetings. While some attendees would strongly prefer to have an in-person meeting, the goals for this meeting to provide a meaningful, engaging, and positive event that was safe and online successfully met community expectations.
